messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the 1950s, companies in Central America had a problem. They sold a banana called the Gros Michel. People also called it Big Mike. This banana made a lot of money. But it was starting to die.

Now, the same thing is happening again. It is happening to the Cavendish banana. The Cavendish is the banana that came after Big Mike.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular. It was easy to move. It had thick skin and it was sweet. It was the main banana on the big farms in Central America.

A company called United Fruit grew these bananas. It was the main company in South America at that time. It grew a lot of bananas in the best way. They did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they took parts from old plants to make new plants. They put many plants close together in the fields.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6115 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a critical failure to preserve the core message of the original text.

Detailed Deviations:
- Core Meaning Lost: The original text describes a business crisis ('most lucrative product', 'dominated') and industrial-scale production ('mass-produced', 'most efficient'). Your version weakens this to simple statements like 'made a lot of money' and 'grew a lot of bananas in the best way'. This oversimplification loses the essential concepts of financial dependency and industrial efficiency.
- Vocabulary Violation: The word 'central' is B1 level. It was used without simplification or definition, violating the A2 vocabulary standard.

Suggestion: Rephrase to restore the lost meaning. The phrase 'made a lot of money' does not capture the meaning of 'most lucrative product'. The phrase 'in the best way' does not capture the meaning of 'mass-produced... in the most efficient way possible'. Replace the B1 word 'central'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the 1950s, companies in the middle of America had a problem. They sold a banana called the Gros Michel. People also called it Big Mike. This banana was their most important product. It made them the most money. But it was starting to die.

Now, the same thing is happening again. It is happening to the Cavendish banana. The Cavendish is the banana that came after Big Mike.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular. It was easy to move. It had thick skin and it was sweet. It was the main banana on the big farms in the middle of America.

A company called United Fruit grew these bananas. It was the main company in South America at that time. It grew many bananas in a very fast and cheap way. They did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they took parts from old plants to make new plants. They put many plants close together in the fields.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6258 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. The text fails to preserve the core message of the original source.

- Primary Failure: The low MeaningBERT score indicates a critical loss of meaning. The original text's concept of a 'lucrative product' is not adequately replaced by 'important product'. While you added 'It made them the most money', the initial simplification weakened the sentence's core meaning, causing the metric failure.
- Secondary Failure: The BERTScore of 0.895 is below the minimum requirement of 0.90. This fidelity loss is caused by replacing specific terminology like 'Central American commercial banana growers' with the vague phrase 'companies in the middle of America'.
- Factual Precision Lost: The term 'Central America' is a specific geographical location. Replacing it with 'the middle of America' is an unacceptable oversimplification that introduces ambiguity and reduces factual accuracy.
- Weakened Concepts: The original phrase 'dominated the plantations' implies total control and market saturation. Your version, 'was the main banana on the big farms', is a weak substitute that loses this essential meaning.

Suggestion: Restore the original meaning. Use the correct term 'Central America'. Rephrase to better capture the concept of 'lucrative', for example: 'This banana was their product that made the most money'. Rephrase to capture the meaning of 'dominated', for example: 'It was the only banana grown on the big farms in Central America'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the 1950s, banana companies in Central America had a problem. They sold a banana called the Gros Michel. People also called it Big Mike. This banana was their product that made the most money. But it was starting to die.

Now, the same thing is happening again. It is happening to the Cavendish banana. The Cavendish is the banana that came after Big Mike.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular. It was easy to move. It had thick skin and it was sweet. It grew on almost all the big farms in Central America.

A company called United Fruit grew these bananas. It was the main company in South America at that time. It grew many bananas in a very fast and cheap way. They did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they took parts from old plants to make new plants. They put many plants close together in the fields.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6311 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a critical failure to preserve the core message of the original text.

- Primary Failure: The original text conveys a sense of business crisis with phrases like 'facing the death of their most lucrative product' and 'most efficient way possible'. Your version, 'had a problem' and 'fast and cheap way', oversimplifies these concepts and loses the essential meaning of a financial threat and industrial optimization. The core message is diluted from a business problem to a simple story.

- Vocabulary Violation: The word 'central' is classified as B1. It was not simplified, violating the A2 vocabulary constraints.

- Suggestion: Rephrase to restore the original meaning. The concept of 'lucrative' must be represented more accurately, for example: 'the product that made them the most money was dying'. The concept of 'efficient' must be restored. Instead of 'fast and cheap', use a phrase that explains the concept in A2 terms, such as 'a way to grow the most bananas for the least amount of money'. Replace 'Central America' with 'countries in the middle of America' to adhere to the A2 vocabulary.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the 1950s, banana companies in countries in the middle of America had a big problem. They sold a banana called the Gros Michel. People also called it Big Mike. This banana made them the most money, and it was dying.

Now, the same thing is happening again. It is happening to the Cavendish banana. The Cavendish is the banana that came after Big Mike.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular. It was easy to move. It had thick skin and it was sweet. It grew on almost all the big farms in countries in the middle of America.

A company called United Fruit grew these bananas. It was the main company in South America at that time. It found a way to grow the most bananas for the least amount of money. They did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they took parts from old plants to make new plants. They put many plants close together in the fields.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6069 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a critical loss of the original text's core message. A secondary failure is the BERTScore of 0.893, which is below the minimum of 0.90.

*   The primary failure is a loss of nuance due to oversimplification. The original text's concepts of business and agricultural scale were not adequately preserved.
*   The term 'lucrative product' was reduced to 'made them the most money'. This loses the specific business context.
*   The concept of a plant 'dominating' plantations was reduced to 'grew on almost all the big farms'. This loses the sense of complete control and scale.
*   The term 'efficient' was simplified to 'for the least amount of money'. This is an incomplete definition; efficiency also implies speed and a lack of waste, which was lost.
*   The removal of key terms like 'commercial growers', 'successor', 'mass-produced', and 'cultivated' caused the low BERTScore, indicating a failure to maintain lexical fidelity.

Suggestion: Rephrase the text to restore the lost business and agricultural concepts using simple A2 phrasing. The goal is simplification, not the complete elimination of core ideas. The current simplification is too aggressive and fails the meaning preservation test.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the 1950s, commercial banana growers in Central America had a big problem. Their most important product for making money was the Gros Michel banana. People also called it Big Mike. This banana was dying.

Now, the same thing is happening again. It is happening to the Cavendish banana. The Cavendish banana is the one that replaced Big Mike.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular. It was easy to move, had thick skin, and was sweet. It was the main banana on almost all the big farms in Central America.

A company called United Fruit grew these bananas. It was the main grower in South America at that time. It found an efficient way to mass-produce them. This means they grew huge numbers of bananas quickly and cheaply. They did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they cloned them by taking parts from old plants. They grew these new plants very close together in the fields.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Vocabulary Standard Violation. The text fails the qualitative audit because it includes vocabulary that exceeds the A2 CEFR level. Adherence to the A2 wordlist is non-negotiable.

- B1 Vocabulary Violation: The word 'commercial' is used in 'commercial banana growers'. This is a B1 word. The A2 standard requires simpler phrasing.
- B1 Vocabulary Violation: The word 'efficient' is used in 'an efficient way'. This is a B1 word. Its presence is an immediate failure.
- B2 Vocabulary Violation: The word 'mass-produce' is B2 level. Explaining the term ('This means they grew huge numbers...') does not excuse its use. The complex term must be removed and replaced entirely by the simple explanation.
- Borderline Meaning Preservation: The MeaningBERT score of 0.7456 is at the absolute minimum threshold for acceptance. This indicates a slight but detectable drift from the original text's core meaning.

Suggestion: Remove all words above the A2 level. Replace 'commercial banana growers' with 'people who grow and sell bananas'. Replace 'an efficient way' with 'a good, fast way'. Do not use the term 'mass-produce'; use only the simple description 'to grow huge numbers of bananas quickly and cheaply'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the 1950s, people who grew and sold bananas in Central America had a big problem. Their most important product for making money was the Gros Michel banana. People also called it Big Mike. This banana was dying.

Now, the same thing is happening again. It is happening to the Cavendish banana. The Cavendish banana is the one that replaced Big Mike.

The Gros Michel banana was very popular. It was easy to move, had thick skin, and was sweet. It was the main banana on almost all the big farms in Central America.

A company called United Fruit grew these bananas. It was the main grower in South America at that time. It found a good, fast way to grow them. They grew huge numbers of bananas quickly and cheaply. They did not grow new plants from seeds. Instead, they cloned them by taking parts from old plants. They grew these new plants very close together in the fields.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6983 is below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a failure to preserve the core message of the original text.

- Primary Deviation: The original text uses the superlative phrase 'the most efficient way possible' to describe the production method. Your version weakens this critical concept to 'a good, fast way'. This loses the essential meaning of maximization and optimization that defined the company's strategy.
- Secondary Deviation: The original states the Gros Michel was the 'most lucrative product'. Your version, 'most important product for making money', is a reasonable simplification but contributes to the overall loss of semantic intensity detected by the metric.

Suggestion: The text must accurately reflect the original's emphasis on peak performance. Rephrase 'a good, fast way to grow them' to 'the best and fastest way to grow them'. This change is required to meet the meaning preservation standard.
